verses.text: I will give thanks to you, O Lord and King, and praise you, God my Savior. I declare your name, for you have been my helper and protector.
verses.comment: The opening sets the tone as a personal thanksgiving, reminiscent of the Psalms. The reference to God as Savior echoes the expectation of God’s deliverance present in Israel’s history and fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: You rescued my body from destruction, and from the snare of a deceitful tongue, and from the lips of those who speak lies.
verses.comment: The psalmist-like theme here connects to deliverance from mortal danger and slander. God’s protection is not solely spiritual, but also physically realized in the life of the faithful.

verses.text: You were my helper against those who rose up against me, and redeemed me according to the greatness of your mercy.
verses.comment: Emphasizes divine mercy and redemption. The concept of being 'redeemed' points forward to Christ’s redemptive work, linking Old Testament deliverance to New Testament salvation.

verses.text: From the multitude of my troubles, from the choking flame all around me, and from a fire I had not kindled;
verses.comment: Evokes images of fiery trial and literal rescue, as in Daniel’s three friends. God's protection is both physical and spiritual.

verses.text: From deep within the belly of Hades, from an unclean tongue and lying speech,
verses.comment: Hades here refers to the shadowy underworld, implying preservation from death. The protection from malicious speech mirrors James 3’s teaching about the tongue.

verses.text: The slander of arrogant enemies was all around me, and my soul was close to death.
verses.comment: The threat is existential; parallels to the suffering servant and Christ’s enemies highlight that suffering often accompanies the righteous.

verses.text: But I remembered your mercy, O Lord, and your works from of old, that you deliver those who put their trust in you.
verses.comment: A call to trust in God, rooted in His historical acts. God’s mercy is ancient and sure—echoes faithfulness to covenant.

verses.text: I raised my voice from the earth and prayed for deliverance from death.
verses.comment: Prayer as supplication in distress. The act of 'raising my voice' anticipates Christian practices of vocal, communal prayer.

verses.text: I called on the Lord, the Father of my Lord: Do not abandon me in the day of my affliction, when proud people attack.
verses.comment: Unique reference—'Father of my Lord'—has messianic overtones. Implies layered meaning, as in Ps. 110:1, where 'my Lord' is applied to the Messiah.

verses.text: I will praise your name continually, and will sing a hymn of thanksgiving.
verses.comment: ‘Sing a hymn’ prefigures liturgical worship, rooted in Psalms and Temple worship—later adapted to Christian liturgy.

verses.text: When my prayer was heard, you saved me from destruction and rescued me from the time of evil.
verses.comment: Prayer is both heard and answered; emphasis on rescue reflects divine responsiveness, and the necessity of persistence in prayer.

verses.text: Therefore I will give thanks and praise you, and will bless the name of the Lord.
verses.comment: Public thanksgiving and blessing God’s name express gratitude, linking personal prayer to communal worship as established in ancient Israel.

verses.text: When I was a youth, before I traveled, I sought wisdom openly in prayer.
verses.comment: Wisdom is sought through prayer, not apart from God. Sets foundation for later teaching that true wisdom is a gift received through discipleship and humility.

verses.text: Before the temple I prayed for her, and I will search for her to the end.
verses.comment: Prayer before the temple highlights the role of sacred space and established worship in seeking wisdom—anticipates the Church’s practice of seeking wisdom through prayer in sacred places.

verses.text: From my blossoming youth she came to me, and I gained wisdom as my inheritance.
verses.comment: Wisdom is described using feminine pronouns, reflecting its personified character in Proverbs. Wisdom is an inheritance—a multifaceted gift received through diligence and grace.

verses.text: I delighted in her and will never forsake her.
verses.comment: Wisdom is central and enduring—never forsaken. The imagery implies commitment, devotion, and life-long seeking, like pursuing virtue or discipleship.

verses.text: My heart was set on searching for her, and because of her, I have gained a good possession.
verses.comment: Wisdom provides both spiritual and material blessings. The connection to wisdom’s practical benefits underlines its importance in daily life.

verses.text: My hands grappled to grasp her; I was not ashamed to cling to her.
verses.comment: Seeking wisdom involves earnest effort, and there is no shame in zealous pursuit of goodness, paralleling Paul’s admonition to 'run the race'.

verses.text: My soul was set on her, and in doing so I was purified. In her, I came to discernment.
verses.comment: Wisdom is purifying, and brings discernment. The cleansing effect of commitment to wisdom aligns with sanctification themes.

verses.text: As a result, I gained understanding; I will not ever abandon her.
verses.comment: Once received, wisdom holds the faithful fast—a bond similar to the commitment believers have to gospel truth.

verses.text: My heart burned for her, I kept watch for her. I followed her in purity and found wisdom.
verses.comment: A depiction of passionate pursuit—suggests that both effort and purity are essential in the spiritual life.

verses.text: With her, I obtained understanding from the start; therefore, I will never be forsaken.
verses.comment: Emphasizes permanence; wisdom, when sought from youth, fosters lifelong faithfulness.

verses.text: My innermost being was stirred to seek her; so I have gained a solid foundation.
verses.comment: A solid foundation is a key wisdom metaphor, later used by Jesus to describe the wise builder. This verse suggests inner yearning leads to spiritual stability.

verses.text: If you desire, receive instruction, and you will profit.
verses.comment: Willingness to learn is required—wisdom is not imposed, but received freely and brings benefit.

verses.text: I opened my mouth and spoke: Gain wisdom for yourselves without money.
verses.comment: Wisdom is offered freely—echoing the ‘without money’ motif of Isaiah 55 regarding God’s grace, and connecting to Christ's free offer of salvation.

verses.text: Bend your neck under her yoke and let your souls receive instruction. She is close to finding.
verses.comment: Taking the yoke of wisdom prefigures Jesus’ invitation to take His yoke; true wisdom comes with humility and discipline.

verses.text: See with your eyes that I have labored little, yet I have found much rest for myself.
verses.comment: A paradox: though effort is made, rest is the result. True wisdom does not weary, but gives peace—anticipates Christ’s teaching on rest for the soul.

verses.text: Acquire instruction with a little silver, and you will gain much gold in her.
verses.comment: Alludes to earthly cost but promises spiritual reward, reminiscent of Jesus’ parables about the treasure hidden in a field.

verses.text: May your soul rejoice in God's mercy, and do not be ashamed to praise him.
verses.comment: Praise grounded in mercy; joy is the fruit of worship, and the link between personal and communal worship is subtle yet present.

verses.text: Finish your work before the appointed time, and God will give you rest at the end.
verses.comment: The promise of final rest alludes to the Sabbath and, in Christian thought, to eternal rest with God. Perseverance is essential, and God’s reward is rest for the soul.
